STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 28, 2022
Zoe Lyons
Jackson County DHHS
301 E Louis Glick Highway
Jackson, MI 49201
RE: License #: CP380201203
Jackson County DHHS
301 E Louis Glick Highway
Jackson, MI 49201
Dear Ms. Lyons:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 1/24/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the previous CAP was unsuccessful and what changes
will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP380201203
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Jackson County DHHS
Facility Address: 301 E Louis Glick Highway
Jackson, MI 49201
Facility Telephone #: (517) 780-7400
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1992
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of six foster home files documented the application was not provided within 60
days prior to expiration. The license expiration was 11/6/21 and the application was
provided on 10/8/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Three of six foster home files held renewal evaluations that were not submitted
within 15 days prior to expiration of the license. Evaluations were submitted at 12, 11
and 4 days prior to expiration.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child's placement.
Two of three borrowed bed files did not have a foster parent agency agreement
signed for 2021 as required by part (1, g) of this rule.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
4

investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
One of one special evaluation was not completed within 45 days and a letter was not
sent to the foster parents until day 57.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated: (iii) A physical
examination every 14 months.
One of eight foster care files held a late medical exam. A medical was due by
January 2021, but it was not completed until 12/20/2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child…
Two of eight foster care files did not have documentation that the information
required by this rule was provided to the foster parents prior to placement or within 7
days for emergency placements.
File one: The child was placed 4/20/21; the placement outline completed 5/3/21.
File two: The child was placed 8/27/21; the placement outline was undated.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of three independent living files did not have documentation to show the
program statement was provided to the youth prior to beginning IL.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
5

One of three independent living files did not have documentation to show the
policies and procedures were provided to the youth prior to beginning IL.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
(c) Provide the youth with a telephone number to contact the
agency on a 24-hour, 7 days a week basis.
Two of three IL case files did not meet the requirements of this rule.
File one did not have a budget on file for October 2021, as required by part (b).
File two did not have documentation that a phone number was provided for the
youth to reach the agency on a 24/7 basis, as required by part (c).
R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three IL case files did not have documentation of contracts reviewed and
provided to the youth at least every 90 days. One file did not have any contracts
uploaded. The second file held one contract for August 2021, but no others.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact.
6

Five of eleven FC and IL files held several contacts that were not entered within 5
business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21
FOM 722-08E Foster care/juvenile justice action summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change.
Four of eleven FC and IL files held incomplete or late DHHS-69 forms.
File one: 11/10/21 caseworker change; DHHS-69 completed 1/20/22.
File two: 4/9/21 move; DHHS-69 completed 5/14/21.
File three: 3/5/21 move; DHHS-69 completed 4/13/21. Also, a DHS-69 was not
completed for a move on 10/4/21.
File four: 5/19/21 move; DHHS-69 completed 11/18/21. 8/27/21 move; DHHS-69
completed 11/28/21. 1/11/22 move; DHHS-69 completed 1/21/22.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to: Participating legal
parents if the child is a temporary court ward. Quarterly, while in
out-of-home placement. The child’s foster care provider: At or
prior to each placement. Quarterly.
7

Four of eleven FC and IL files did not have passports as required.
File one: 10/4/21 passport did not have documentation of being provided to
placement.
File two: Quarterly updates were not on file. Only on passport was completed for
2021.
File three: Quarterly updates were not on file. The last passport on file was from
August 2020.
File four: Quarterly updates were not on file for 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21
FOM 722-06B Family team meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables…
Within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Four of eleven FC and IL files did not have FTMs or 1105 reports as required.
File one: 1105 reports were not completed for three FTMs. An FTM was not
completed within 30 days prior to 1/14/22 USP.
File two: The 10/19/21 1105 was mostly blank.
File three: An FTM was not completed within 30 days prior to 4/27/21 USP.
File four: The 9/16/21 FTM 1105 report was uploaded late (9/27/21)
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21
FOM 722-06I Maintaining connections: Parenting time, sibling
visitations, and contact
Siblings in foster care who are not placed together must have
regular contact. At minimum, siblings placed apart must have
one in-person contact within the first 30 days of the placement
that results in separation and one in-person contact per
calendar month thereafter.
All exceptions must be recorded in MiSACWIS. The caseworker
must document reasonable efforts to ensure in-person sibling
contacts in the case service plan.
8

One of eleven FC and IL files did not have sibling visits documented from
September to December 2021. An approved exception was not on file.
FOM 722-08D PATP signatures
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable…
If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Six of eleven FC and IL files has late or missing PATP signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (Previously cited as FOM 722-08C)
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20.
1/4/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/1/21.
FOM 722-06H Parental visits
The primary foster care caseworker must have face-to-face
contact with the legal parent or guardian at least once per
calendar month. At least one contact each quarter must occur in
the parent’s residence.
One of eight FC files did not have quarterly visits to the parental home.
FOM 801-01 Health requirements
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every six
months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Three of eleven FC and IL files had late or missing dental exams.
File one: One dental was completed 8/24/20; the next was not until 6/29/21. A 6-
month exam was due in February 2021.
File two: The youth’s last dental was on 11/9/20. New dentals were due May 2021
and November 2021.
File three: A dental exam was not on file.
FOM 722-08 Supervisory approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
9

One of eleven FC and IL files held a USP that was approved 9 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
2/12/2020 Interim, CAP approved 3/13/20
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Policy updated on 11/1/21, clarified that PATP signatures are due within 30 days
of the report date. Not the report approval date.
 When a youth over 18 refuses medical or dental care and the 1147 form is
completed, staff must ensure the youth marks the box indicating they were
advised of and given access to medical and dental care.
 All IL rule requirements must be met for YAVFC youth. YAVFC is a service type,
while IL is their placement and requires IL rules to be followed.
 DHHS-69s completed for closing cases of youth over 18 must have the bottom
portion completed to document the required items were provide to the youth at
the time they left care.
 Per recent clarification from the policy office, non-respondent parents that have
placement of their child must sign the PATP and Medical Passport as the
“placement provider”.
 When FTMs are held virtually, the 1105 must document who attended and how.
 If parental signatures on medical passports or PATPs cannot be gathered, the
worker should indicate this information on the signature line and upload the
document within the required timeframe. If the parent later signs, the signature
page should be uploaded in addition to the initial signature page.
 Medical passports must be updated and reviewed with the parent and foster
parent quarterly. Meaning every 90 days.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP, approved 2/1/21, was the result
of the 1/14/21 renewal evaluation. During that review eleven violations were found.
The agency has effectively implemented their CAP from 2021. However, it was
noted that staffing changes and COVID procedures posed some challenges for
ongoing maintenance of the CAP. While there were some repeat violations during
this review, most instances of repeats were low. Overall, the majority of cases
reviewed were thorough and met most requirements.
10

Chief Administrator Assessment
The 2021 Chief Administrator Annual Assessment was reviewed. During this review
it was reported the agency’s last CAP was fully implemented. However, there
continues to be some challenges due to the ongoing pandemic. The agency
continues to have a large number of cases and is adequately staffed at this time.
Training and process adjustments are ongoing to continue improvement in several
areas. Overall, the agency reported strength in many areas, while acknowledging
where improvement is needed over the next year.
Interviews
Two foster care staff were interviewed. One staff has been with the agency for about
five years, while the other staff was new within this past year. Both staff reported
feeling supported by co-workers, supervisors, and administration. Neither staff had
any concerns about the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ _____________January 28, 2022____________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 28, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
